recommendations.title: What Ellen’s Kindness Concealed
recommendations.excerpt: The recent scandal at her talk show suggests that the host’s smiling facade covers up something dark—and hints at why that facade had to be created in the first place.

recommendations.title: The Life and Death of Richard Swift
recommendations.excerpt: His work with the Black Keys and the Shins made him one of rock’s most valuable sidemen and producers, but addiction brought him down.

recommendations.title: “You Can Never See Their Pants for Some Reason”
recommendations.excerpt: Teens explain the VSCO girl—and why you never want to be one.

recommendations.title: Coronavirus: Editors’ Picks
recommendations.excerpt: How long-lingering symptoms are redefining our understanding of COVID-19.

recommendations.title: What Coffee-Brewing Method Makes the Best-Tasting Cup?
recommendations.excerpt: I tried 5 methods to make italian-style coffee at home. The winner was clear and surprising!

recommendations.title: ‘The Bed That Saved Me From the Taliban’
recommendations.excerpt: In 2018, Greek pilot Vasileios Vasileiou checked into a luxury hilltop hotel in Kabul that was popular among foreign visitors. Then Taliban gunmen stormed it, killing at least 40 people. Vasileios explains how he survived.

recommendations.title: How a designer used AI and Photoshop to bring ancient Roman emperors back to life
recommendations.excerpt: Transforming statues into photorealistic faces with AI.

recommendations.title: Henry Johnson, the One-Man Army Who Fought Off Dozens of German Soldiers During World War I
recommendations.excerpt: In May 1918, Henry Johnson found himself alone in the Argonne with a wounded ally, an empty rifle, and dozens of German soldiers closing in. He didn’t run. He fought.

recommendations.title: Why There Are So Few Moderate Republicans Left
recommendations.excerpt: And why that’s not likely to change.

recommendations.title: What Stephen Hawking’s Final Paper Really Means
recommendations.excerpt: The world-famous astrophysicist’s last contribution to science shows both his dedication to “normal science” and his willingness to ask questions that shape how we think about life.

recommendations.title: The Hidden Queer History Behind “A League of Their Own”
recommendations.excerpt: The All-American Girls Professional Baseball League did everything it could to keep lesbians off the diamond. Seventy-five years later, its gay stars are finally opening up.

recommendations.title: Octavia Butler on How (Not) to Choose Our Leaders
recommendations.excerpt: “To be led by a coward is to be controlled by all that the coward fears. To be led by a fool is to be led by the opportunists who control the fool.”

recommendations.title: Earth’s Orbital Shifts May Have Triggered Ancient Global Warming
recommendations.excerpt: A study suggests the Paleocene-Eocene Thermal Maximum may have been instigated by subtle shifts in Earth’s orbit around the sun.

recommendations.title: How to Complain and Get Results
recommendations.excerpt: Impersonal customer service makes it hard to get help. Here’s the script for success.

recommendations.title: This Single Step Has Changed My Meal-Prep Attitude Forever
recommendations.excerpt: Game-changing sauce recipes.

recommendations.title: Why Interstellar Travel Is so Damn Hard
recommendations.excerpt: If you’re wondering why taking a trip to another star is incredibly difficult, blame physics.

recommendations.title: Why Venice Is Disappearing
recommendations.excerpt: Flooding in the historic city is about more than climate change — bad engineering and corruption are also to blame.

recommendations.title: A Long-Lost Manuscript Contains a Searing Eyewitness Account of the Tulsa Race Massacre
recommendations.excerpt: An Oklahoma lawyer details the 1921 attack by hundreds of whites on the thriving black neighborhood where hundreds died.

recommendations.title: “Stress Hormone” Cortisol Linked to Early Toll on Thinking Ability
recommendations.excerpt: The stresses of everyday life may start taking a toll on the brain in relatively early middle age, new research shows.

recommendations.title: The Mysterious Bronze Objects that Have Baffled Archaeologists for Centuries
recommendations.excerpt: The first dodecahedron was discovered nearly 300 years ago, yet no one is certain just what they were used for.
